I think the majority of enterprises should start with "everything in area 0" unless:
1 - Summarisation in order to make the route tables slightly more human friendly.
2 - Reduced failure domain. Want to exchange routes with a firewall? Have lots of WAN links where you expect a fair amount of churn? Here's an area (or two) for those.

comments.html: Mobile backhaul is a good example of an multi-area topology - suppose you have a hub (with 2 routers) and 2-3K spokes (cell sites and link going to each hub router, ie. 2 uplinks per cell site). In this scenario cell router is quite simple piece of hardware with basic OSPF NSSA support. The link between hub routers used as intra-area connection (i.e. 2-3k vlans per hub-spoke topology). Hub routers advertise summarized route to the backbone, operator have flexibility to have ECMP or active/standby configuration on a per-cell site basis. With modern routing hardware on a hub side you can enable various additional features such as non-stop routing...
